ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Coupling effect of spiral-shaped terahertz metamaterials for tunable electromagnetic response

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Coupling effect in spiral-shaped metamaterials composed of four half rings at different sizes is investigated to achieve tunability in THz range. This novel spiral-shaped structure was fabricated on flexible substrate with laser micro-lens array (MLA) lithography and measured by THz time domain spectroscopy (THz-TDS). The experimental results suggest that mutual capacitance and inductance coupling in the spiral-shaped structure would result in frequency shifts of the four resonances. The observed shifting trends of the four resonant frequencies are in good agreement with simulation and are further explained by the electric field distribution. By varying the gap sizes among the half rings, four resonant frequencies can be tuned flexibly. Such a spiral-shaped design has potential applications in multi-band tunable THz MEMS devices.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: THz metamaterials, a novel class of artificially engineered media, provide strong electromagnetic interactions with THz waves. Compared with conventional bulky materials, THz metamaterials allow the effective manipulation of the electromagnetic properties in terms of permittivity and permeability [1, 2], which attract much research attention and promise a family of exciting applications such as THz imaging for security [3, 4], THz sensing for biotechnology [5, 6] and THz communications [7, 8].

To realize these THz applications, a large amount of research has been carried out in recent years, such as passive tunable THz metamaterials by changing shape, size, and orientation of split ring resonators (SRRs) [9, 10], active tunable THz metamaterials under optical pumping [11], heating [12], electrical field [13] and mechanical forces [14]. Among all these tunable THz metamaterials, near-field coupling among unit cells is one of the prominent electromagnetic properties [15], which changes the fundamental resonant frequency of each unit cell and can be used to make tunable THz devices [16, 17]. Recently some researchers have investigated the near-field coupling among SRRs in terms of lattice size and orientation [18]. Both the electric and the magnetic couplings have been studied [19, 20]. Meanwhile, long-range diffractive coupling is also investigated for higher order resonances [19, 21]. However, most research on the coupling effect is based on SRRs at a same size, which can only work at one single wavelength.

In this paper, a novel spiral-shaped THz metamaterial formed by four half rings at different sizes is studied. The coupling effect among the four half rings is investigated to achieve tunable THz metamaterials at the four resonant frequencies. In one unit cell, the four half rings are connected in a spiral shape with a small gap, which introduces mutual capacitance and inductance coupling among different half rings. This design causes the fundamental resonant frequencies either red or blue shift. By increasing the gap size, the coupling effect among the half rings can be tuned agilely. Such a spiral shaped structure promises a novel approach to tune four resonant frequencies and can be applied for multi-band THz applications.

Section1.Heading: Design, experiments, and simulation
Section1.Para:
As shown in Fig. 1(a), the outer radii of four copper (Cu) half rings R1, R2, R3, and R4 are 15, 20, 25, and 30 μm, respectively. The width of all the half rings is 5 μm. Four half rings are arranged in the spiral-shape at a gap d of 2 μm at a square lattice dimension of 100 μm and the electric field of the incident wave is parallel to the gap.
Fig. 1
(a) Schematic of the spiral-shaped metamaterials. Four half rings are arranged in a spiral shape at a small gap. The electric field of the incident wave is parallel to the gap. (b) Microscopic image of spiral-shaped metamaterials fabricated by the laser MLA lithography. The scale bar is 200 μm

The spiral-shaped metamaterials were fabricated by laser MLA lithography. The substrate is polyethylene naphthalate (PEN) films with 100 μm thickness, which is transparent to THz wave and enables flexible applications on the non-planar surfaces. Positive photoresist S1813 was firstly coated onto the PEN film by a spin coater, followed by a soft-baking using a hotplate. Then the spiral-shaped pattern was created on the photoresist layer with the laser MLA lithography. The exposed photoresist was developed in MF319 developer. Cu film at the thickness of 200 nm was deposited on the samples by electron beam evaporation and followed with lift-off to form the designed structure.

The microscopic image of the fabricated spiral-shaped THz metamaterials is shown in Fig. 1(b). The fabricated spiral-shaped structures were uniform over an area of 1×0.5 cm2. The size of the unit cell is 100 μm and the gap size is 2 μm. The measured transmission spectra were obtained by the THz-TDS system inside nitrogen environment, which attenuates the water absorption in THz range. Numerical simulation was performed using finite-difference time-domain method (FDTD Solutions 8.5, Lumerical Inc.) to study the coupling effect among different half rings.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
In this spiral-shaped metamaterial, each half ring can be regarded as a SRR and excites inductive-capacitive (LC) resonances. The fundamental LC resonance occurs when electrons in the half ring collectively oscillate along the full half ring loop. The resonant frequency of each half ring can be described by the equation
$\omega_{L} =1/\sqrt{LC}$ , where L is the effective inductance and C the effective capacitance of each half ring. As shown in the simulation results of Fig. 2(a), when four half rings R1, R2, R3, and R4 are individually designed at a period of 100 μm, which is the same as the unit cell size in the spiral structure, four different resonant frequencies are observed at 2.016, 1.718, 1.429 and 1.205 THz, respectively. This is due to the fact that the radii of the half rings are different, leading to different effective inductance and capacitance, which determine different resonant frequencies. Based on the simulation results, smaller half rings resonate at higher frequencies. When these four half rings are arranged in the spiral structure at the gap of 2 μm, the resonant frequencies of R1, R2, and R3 shift to higher frequencies at 2.205, 1.801 and 1.440 THz, respectively. However, the resonant frequency of R4 shifts to a lower frequency at 1.000 THz. For the experimental results shown in Fig. 2(b), four half rings R4, R3, R2, and R1 individually resonate at 0.764, 0.959, 1.424 and 1.678 THz, respectively. When the four half rings are arranged into the spiral-shaped structure at the gap size of 2 μm as shown in Fig. 1(b), R4 resonant frequency shifts to a lower frequency at 0.734 THz and the other three resonant frequencies of R3, R2, and R1 shift to higher frequencies at 0.974, 1.454 and 1.723 THz, respectively. Due to the substrate effect and the materials utilized in the simulation being treated as perfect electrical conductors, the resonant frequencies in the simulation are some different from the experimental results. However, the shifting trends of four resonant frequencies in the simulation and experimental results are in good agreement.
Fig. 2
Simulation and experimental results of the transmission spectra. (a) Simulated transmission spectra of individual four half rings and our designed spiral shaped structure at the gap of 2 μm. (b) Measured transmission spectra of individual four half rings and the spiral shaped structure at the gap of 2 μm. (c) Illustration of the LC circuit model for the half ring R1. (d) Illustration of the LC circuit model for the half ring R1 in the spiral shaped structure

These resonant frequencies shifting trends in both simulation and experimental results indicate a strong coupling effect in this spiral-shaped structure. In order to illustrate these shifting trends, a LC model is used as shown in Figs. 2(c) and (d). An inductor L and a capacitor C are defined to describe the resonance of the half ring as shown in Fig. 2(c). When the half ring is arranged into this novel spiral-shaped design, the mutual capacitance coupling in the gap introduces an additional gap capacitance, which is parallel to the original capacitor of the half ring. Thus the effective capacitance increases based on the equation C eff=C+C add, where C eff is the effective capacitance, C is the original capacitance and C add is the coupled capacitance. In this spiral-shaped structure, mutual inductance coupling among different half rings introduces an extra inductance as the coupled inductors are parallel to each other, making the effective inductance decrease as
$\frac{1}{L_{\mathrm{eff}}} = \frac{1}{L} + \frac{1}{L_{\mathrm{add}}}$ , where L eff is the effective inductance, L is the original inductance and L add is the coupled inductance. Therefore, the resonant frequency of the half ring in the spiral-shaped design can be described by Eq. (1) for approximation as: 1
$$ \omega_{L} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{\frac{1}{L} +\frac{1}{L_{\mathrm{add}}}} (C+C_{\mathrm{add}}} )} $$ where ω
L is the resonant frequency. Equation (1) indicates that mutual capacitance coupling in the gap results in a red shift of the resonant frequencies and mutual inductance coupling among the half rings leads to a blue shift of the resonant frequencies. In both the simulation and the experimental results, the resonant frequency of R4 shifts to a lower frequency when it is arranged into the spiral structure. This means the mutual capacitance coupling dominates the overall coupling effect and leads to the red shift of the resonant frequency. The resonant frequencies of R1, R2, and R3 shift to the higher frequencies, suggesting the mutual inductance coupling dominates the whole coupling effect. Meanwhile, the shifting range of the resonant frequency of R3 is relative small compared with the shifting range of other three resonant frequencies in both the simulation and the experimental results. This result indicates that both the mutual capacitance and the inductance couplings affect the effective capacitance and inductance, leading to a small shift of the resonant frequency.

In order to explain the mutual capacitance and inductance coupling effects in this spiral-shaped structure, the electric field distributions at 1.000, 1.440, 1.801, and 2.205 THz are plotted. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the electric field is enhanced in the gap. This electric field enhancement in the gap indicates the existence of the mutual capacitance coupling, which increases the effective capacitance of R4. This agrees with the red shift of the fundamental LC resonance of R4. Figure 3(b) shows that electric field is also enhanced in the gap of R3. However, the mutual inductance coupling between R4 and R2 is also observed as shown in the green part in Fig. 3(b). This mutual inductance coupling leads to the decrease of the effective inductance, resulting in a blue shift of the fundamental LC resonance. The overall effect of mutual capacitance and inductance coupling explains the small resonant frequency shift of R3. The electric field distribution in Fig. 3(c) shows the electric field enhancement in the gap between R1 and R2. The green part in Fig. 3(c) indicates mutual inductance coupling between R1 and R3. The blue shift of R2 suggests that the mutual inductance coupling dominate the overall coupling effect. In Fig. 3(d), the green part shows that the mutual inductance coupling between R1 and R3 dominate the coupling effect, causing the blue shift of the fundamental resonant frequency of R1. The red shift of R4 and blue shift of R1, R2, and R3 show that this spiral shaped design combines the four half rings into one unit cell and the coupling among different half rings changes the electromagnetic properties of each half ring. This coupling effect in the spiral shaped design promises a novel method to tune four resonant frequencies and the hot spots can be selectively excited at different frequencies.
Fig. 3
Simulated electric field distributions at the gap of 2 μm at (a) 1.000, (b) 1.440, (c) 1.801 and (d) 2.205 THz, respectively

Figure 4 shows the simulated transmission spectra when the gap increases from 2 to 5 μm and the electric field distributions at the gap of 5 μm and at 1.073, 1.474, 1.837, and 2.219 THz, respectively. As shown in Fig. 4(a), when the gap size increases to 5 μm, the four resonant frequencies shift from 1.000, 1.440, 1.801, and 2.205 THz to higher frequencies at 1.073, 1.474, 1.837, and 2.219 THz, respectively. This blue shift arises from the fact that when the gap size increases, the additional gap capacitance decreases, making the effective capacitance C eff decrease. However, the effective inductance L eff remains unchanged as the relative positions between R4 and R2, R3, and R1 are the same and the inductance coupling does not change. Therefore, the shifting trends of the four resonant frequencies are dominated by the mutual capacitance coupling. Figure 4(b) shows the electric field distribution at the gap of 5 μm and at 1.073 THz. The amplitude of the electric field in the gap is smaller in Fig. 4(b) (maximum: 41) than the amplitude of the electric field in Fig. 3(a) (maximum: 78), suggesting the coupling intensity decreases when the gap size increases. The amplitudes of the electric field in the gap in Figs. 4(c)∼(e) are also smaller (maximum: 37, 27, and 29) compared with those in Figs. 3(b)∼(d) (maximum: 47, 39, and 31). Therefore, the decrease of the coupling intensity in the gap reduces the effective capacitance C eff while the effective inductance L eff remains unchanged, leading to the blue shift of the four resonant frequencies. This gap variation paves a novel approach to get tunable electromagnetic responses for multi-band THz applications when such a design is integrated into MEMS devices.
Fig. 4
(a) Simulation results of the transmission spectra at gaps of 2 and 5 μm. Simulated electric field distributions at the gap of 5 μm and at (b) 1.073, (c) 1.474, (d) 1.837 and (e) 2.219 THz, respectively

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, a novel spiral-shaped THz metamaterial formed by four different half rings was fabricated with laser MLA lithography and characterized by THz-TDS system. The coupling effect among four half rings was investigated to tune electromagnetic responses. Both the experimental and simulation results suggest that in this spiral structure, the mutual capacitance coupling among different half rings results in a red shift of the resonant frequency and the mutual inductance coupling among different half rings leads to a blue shift of the resonant frequency. By varying the gap size, four resonant frequencies can be tuned at a same time. These two coupling mechanisms in such a spiral shaped design and the gap size variation can be exploited in the multi-band tunable THz metamaterials research.
